Instructions
 
       
 

Review the following steps to complete this questionnaire:

1) Answer questions. Select the appropriate answer to each question. Question specific help text may be available via the icon. If your answer dictates an explanation, a required text box will become available for you to add further information.

2) Add Comments. You may add question specific comments or attach supporting evidence for your answers by clicking on the icon next to each question. Once you have saved the comment, the icon will change to the icon to show that a comment has been added.

3) Change the Status. You may keep the questionnaire in the "In Process" status until you are ready to submit it for review. When you have completed the assessment, change the Submission Status to "Submitted". This will route the assessment to the proper reviewer. Please note that all values list questions must be answered before submitting the questionnaire.

4) Save/Exit the Questionnaire. You may use any of the four buttons at the top and bottom of the screen to save or exit the questionnaire. The button allows you to complete the questionnaire. The button allows you to save your work and close the questionnaire. The button allows you to save your work and remain in the questionnaire. The button closes the questionnaire without saving your work.

9/1/2025

Our Access Control and Identity Management Policy establishes segregation of duties as a core security principle, stating that "Critical functions require multiple people" to ensure no single individual has complete control over sensitive operations.

This policy establishes clear segregation through defined roles:

1) Technical Staff: Infrastructure management (separate from business functions)
2) Management: Business systems access (separate from technical operations)
3) Administrative Functions: Require dual authorization and separate admin accounts

AWS Infrastructure Controls:
  • AWS IAM policies enforce role-based permissions with principle of least privilege
  • Resource tagging enables automated policy enforcement by data classification
  • Database-level controls with separate user accounts and schemas by sensitivity
  • Encryption key separation using AWS KMS customer-managed keys for different data classifications
ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-IAM-06.2
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/1/2025

Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy establishes multiple layers of protection for source code and applications. All code is stored in version-controlled Git repositories with role-based access controls, where only authorized technical staff have repository access based on their specific responsibilities. We implement secure development lifecycle controls including mandatory peer code reviews with security checklists, automated security scanning in our CI/CD pipeline (static analysis via SonarQube, dependency scanning, secret scanning), and environment separation ensuring production code access is strictly limited to essential personnel. Additionally, our Access Control and Identity Management Policy enforces principle of least privilege with separate credentials for each environment, comprehensive access logging, and semi-annual reviews for administrative access to development systems.

ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-IVS-07.1
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/1/2025

Yes, IBP implements hardened operating systems with only the necessary ports, protocols, and services. Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy establishes "Security-hardened AMIs for all EC2 instances" with comprehensive technical controls. These include automated patch management via AWS Systems Manager, monitoring through CloudWatch and GuardDuty, and Infrastructure as Code with drift detection.

Network Security Controls

• Security Groups: Application-level firewalls with "explicit allow rules only."

• Network ACLs: Subnet-level security controls as an additional defense layer.

• AWS WAF: Web application firewall protection.

• Multi-tier VPC: /16 CIDR block across three Availability Zones with isolated subnets.

Hardening Implementation

  • Service Deactivation: Unnecessary programs and services are deactivated.
  • Privileged Control: AWS IAM policies restrict the usage of privileged programs.
  • File Share Restrictions: S3 buckets have "Public access blocked unless specifically required."
  • Regular Security Checks: Vulnerability scans and continuous compliance monitoring.

Current Infrastructure

• OS: Security-hardened AMIs (m5.large minimum).

• Monitoring: Comprehensive logging via CloudWatch, GuardDuty, and CloudTrail.

• Compliance: AWS Config rules for continuous compliance verification.

Documentation Available

Under NDA, we provide complete hardening guidelines, specific port configurations, OS versions, and security baseline documentation. All configurations are maintained through version-controlled Infrastructure as Code with automated compliance monitoring.

 
ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-IVS-09.1
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/1/2025

Yes, IBP's system and network environments are protected by multiple firewall layers to ensure business and customer security requirements.

Application-Level Firewalls:
- Security Groups: Application-level firewalls with "explicit allow rules only" - this implements a default deny-all policy where ports are opened only as needed
- Network ACLs: Subnet-level security controls providing additional defense layers

Web Application Firewall:
- AWS WAF: Protects against OWASP Top 10 threats for all public-facing applications
- Runtime Protection: Real-time protection for web applications and customer-facing services
- Default Deny Policy Implementation

"Deny All" Default Settings:
- Security Groups: "Explicit allow rules only" - implements strict default deny with selective port opening
- Network Segmentation: Multi-tier VPC with isolated subnets (public, private application, isolated database)
- Port Management: Ports opened only based on documented business requirements

ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-SEF-01.1
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/2/2025

Yes, IBP has a comprehensive documented security incident response plan outlined in our Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy. Our incident response framework includes a dedicated Incident Response Team (IRT). The plan establishes a four-tier incident severity classification system (Critical, High, Medium, Low) with specific response times ranging from immediate response for critical incidents to 72 hours for low-impact issues.

Our documented procedures cover the complete incident lifecycle including immediate response actions (0-1 hour), short-term response (1-24 hours), and recovery/resolution (24+ hours), with detailed detection mechanisms using AWS CloudWatch and GuardDuty, comprehensive communication protocols, and specific GDPR breach response procedures requiring 72-hour regulatory notification.

The plan also includes business continuity management with defined Recovery Time Objectives (RTOs) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPOs) for critical systems like our BMS application (4-hour RTO, 1-hour RPO), regular testing schedules with monthly backup verification and quarterly tabletop exercises, and post-incident analysis procedures to ensure continuous improvement of our incident response capabilities.
ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-SEF-02.2
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/2/2025

Our Incident Response Policy establishes customer communication protocols with notification timelines. Critical incidents require immediate notification to affected customers, with formal incident notification templates and status updates throughout resolution. We commit to 24-hour notification for confirmed security incidents affecting customer data, with enhanced communication for high-severity incidents.
ViewCSA-CAIQv3.1-SEF-03.1
  • Ribaut, Jean-Marcel
9/2/2025

Our Remote Work Security Policy establishes formal incident reporting obligations for all personnel with clear escalation procedures. We utilize AWS-native SIEM capabilities including CloudWatch for monitoring, GuardDuty for threat detection, and CloudTrail for comprehensive API logging.

 

We operate a centralized SIEM solution based on AWS CloudTrail, AWS Config, and CloudWatch, integrated into a broader monitoring framework. All API calls, configuration changes, and resource modifications are logged. Specific categories of events that are logged and monitored include:

 

Audit record changes: Configuration drift, unauthorized modifications to CloudTrail or logging infrastructure.

Privilege escalations: Attempts to assign or assume elevated IAM roles or policies.

Ownership or control changes: Unauthorized modifications to resource ownership or security groups.

Authentication events: Multiple failed logins, anomalous login patterns, and unauthorized access attempts.

Alerts are automatically generated through CloudWatch Alarms and AWS GuardDuty when thresholds are exceeded or suspicious activity is detected, such as:

Any change to audit log settings (threshold = 1 event).

Unauthorized privilege escalation attempts (threshold = 1 event).

Ownership takeovers or policy hijacks (threshold = 1 event).

Excessive failed login attempts (threshold = 5 consecutive failures).
